trans-unit.source: How to install and configure Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to install and configure Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Learn how to install and configure Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to install and configure Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: How to install and configure Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to install and configure Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: PowerShellAzure CLI
trans-unit.target: PowerShellAzure CLI

trans-unit.source: You can use Windows PowerShell to perform a variety of tasks in Azure, either interactively at a command prompt or automatically through scripts.
trans-unit.target: You can use Windows PowerShell to perform a variety of tasks in Azure, either interactively at a command prompt or automatically through scripts.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell is a module that provides cmdlets to manage Azure through Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can use the cmdlets to create, test, deploy, and manage solutions and services delivered through the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: You can use the cmdlets to create, test, deploy, and manage solutions and services delivered through the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, you can use the cmdlets to perform the same tasks that you can perform through the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, you can use the cmdlets to perform the same tasks that you can perform through the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can create and configure cloud services, virtual machines, virtual networks, and web apps.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can create and configure cloud services, virtual machines, virtual networks, and web apps.

trans-unit.source: The module is distributed as a downloadable file and the source code is managed through a publicly available repository.
trans-unit.target: The module is distributed as a downloadable file and the source code is managed through a publicly available repository.

trans-unit.source: A link to the downloadable files is provided in the installation instructions later in this topic.
trans-unit.target: A link to the downloadable files is provided in the installation instructions later in this topic.

trans-unit.source: For information about the source code, see [Azure PowerShell code repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell).
trans-unit.target: For information about the source code, see [Azure PowerShell code repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell).

trans-unit.source: This guide provides basic information about installing and setting up Azure PowerShell to manage the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: This guide provides basic information about installing and setting up Azure PowerShell to manage the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites for using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites for using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Azure is a subscription-based platform.
trans-unit.target: Azure is a subscription-based platform.

trans-unit.source: This means that a subscription is required to use the platform.
trans-unit.target: This means that a subscription is required to use the platform.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, it also means that the cmdlets require subscription information to perform the tasks with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, it also means that the cmdlets require subscription information to perform the tasks with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: (Some of the storage-related cmdlets can be used without this information.) You provide this by configuring your computer to connect to your subscription.
trans-unit.target: (Some of the storage-related cmdlets can be used without this information.) You provide this by configuring your computer to connect to your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Instructions are provided in this article, under "How to: Connect to your subscription."
trans-unit.target: Instructions are provided in this article, under "How to: Connect to your subscription."

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Beginning in version 0.8.5, the Azure PowerShell modules require Microsoft .NET Framework 4.5.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Beginning in version 0.8.5, the Azure PowerShell modules require Microsoft .NET Framework 4.5.

trans-unit.source: When you install the module, the installer checks your system for the required software and installs all dependencies, such as the correct version of Windows PowerShell and .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: When you install the module, the installer checks your system for the required software and installs all dependencies, such as the correct version of Windows PowerShell and .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: How to: Install Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: How to: Install Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the Azure PowerShell modules by running the [Microsoft Web Platform Installer](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320376).
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the Azure PowerShell modules by running the [Microsoft Web Platform Installer](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320376).

trans-unit.source: When prompted, click **Run**.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, click **Run**.

trans-unit.source: The Web Platform Installer installs the Azure PowerShell modules and all dependencies.
trans-unit.target: The Web Platform Installer installs the Azure PowerShell modules and all dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts to complete the installation.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts to complete the installation.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you just want to download the PowerShell installer, please visit https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/releases.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you just want to download the PowerShell installer, please visit https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/releases.

trans-unit.source: Source code for the PowerShell cmdlets can be found at this repo as well
trans-unit.target: Source code for the PowerShell cmdlets can be found at this repo as well

trans-unit.source: For more information about the command-line tools available for Azure, see [Command-line tools]( http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=320796).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the command-line tools available for Azure, see [Command-line tools]( http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=320796).

trans-unit.source: Installing the module also installs a customized console for Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Installing the module also installs a customized console for Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can run the cmdlets from either the standard Windows PowerShell console or the Azure PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: You can run the cmdlets from either the standard Windows PowerShell console or the Azure PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: The method you use to open either console depends on the version of Windows you're running:
trans-unit.target: The method you use to open either console depends on the version of Windows you're running:

trans-unit.source: On a computer running at least Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012, you can use the built-in Search.
trans-unit.target: On a computer running at least Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012, you can use the built-in Search.

trans-unit.source: From the Start screen, begin typing **power**.
trans-unit.target: From the Start screen, begin typing **power**.

trans-unit.source: This returns a scoped list of apps that includes Windows PowerShell and Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This returns a scoped list of apps that includes Windows PowerShell and Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: To open the console, click either app.
trans-unit.target: To open the console, click either app.

trans-unit.source: (To pin the app to the Start screen, right-click the icon.)
trans-unit.target: (To pin the app to the Start screen, right-click the icon.)

trans-unit.source: On a computer running a version earlier than Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012, use the Start menu.
trans-unit.target: On a computer running a version earlier than Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012, use the Start menu.

trans-unit.source: From the Start menu, click **All Programs**, click **Azure**, and then click **Azure PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: From the Start menu, click **All Programs**, click **Azure**, and then click **Azure PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: How to: Connect to your subscription
trans-unit.target: How to: Connect to your subscription

trans-unit.source: Use of Azure requires a subscription.
trans-unit.target: Use of Azure requires a subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have a subscription, see [Get Started with Azure](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320795).
trans-unit.target: If you don't have a subscription, see [Get Started with Azure](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320795).

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets need your subscription so they can manage your services.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets need your subscription so they can manage your services.

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to provide your subscription information to Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to provide your subscription information to Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can use a management certificate that contains the information or you can sign in to Azure using your Microsoft account or a work or school account.
trans-unit.target: You can use a management certificate that contains the information or you can sign in to Azure using your Microsoft account or a work or school account.

trans-unit.source: When you sign in, Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) authenticates the credentials and returns an access token that lets Azure PowerShell manage your account.
trans-unit.target: When you sign in, Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) authenticates the credentials and returns an access token that lets Azure PowerShell manage your account.

trans-unit.source: To help you choose the authentication method that's appropriate for your needs, consider the following:
trans-unit.target: To help you choose the authentication method that's appropriate for your needs, consider the following:

trans-unit.source: Azure AD is the recommended authentication method since it makes it easier to manage access to a subscription.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD is the recommended authentication method since it makes it easier to manage access to a subscription.

trans-unit.source: With the update in version 0.8.6, it enables an automation scenario with Azure AD authentication as well if a work or school account is used.
trans-unit.target: With the update in version 0.8.6, it enables an automation scenario with Azure AD authentication as well if a work or school account is used.

trans-unit.source: It works with Azure Resource Manager API as well.
trans-unit.target: It works with Azure Resource Manager API as well.

trans-unit.source: When you use the certificate method, the subscription information is available as long as the subscription and the certificate are valid.
trans-unit.target: When you use the certificate method, the subscription information is available as long as the subscription and the certificate are valid.

trans-unit.source: However, this method makes it harder to manage access to a shared subscription, such as when more than one person is authorized to access the account.
trans-unit.target: However, this method makes it harder to manage access to a shared subscription, such as when more than one person is authorized to access the account.

trans-unit.source: Also, Azure Resource Manager API doesn't accept certificate authentication.
trans-unit.target: Also, Azure Resource Manager API doesn't accept certificate authentication.

trans-unit.source: For more information about authentication and subscription management in Azure, see [Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=324796).
trans-unit.target: For more information about authentication and subscription management in Azure, see [Manage Accounts, Subscriptions, and Administrative Roles](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=324796).

trans-unit.source: Use the Azure AD method
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure AD method

trans-unit.source: Open the Azure PowerShell console, as instructed in [How to: Install Azure PowerShell](#Install).
trans-unit.target: Open the Azure PowerShell console, as instructed in [How to: Install Azure PowerShell](#Install).

trans-unit.source: Type the following command:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command:

trans-unit.source: In the window, type the email address and password associated with your account.
trans-unit.target: In the window, type the email address and password associated with your account.

trans-unit.source: Azure authenticates and saves the credential information, and then closes the window.
trans-unit.target: Azure authenticates and saves the credential information, and then closes the window.

trans-unit.source: Starting from 0.8.6, if you sign in using a work or school account, you can type the following command to bypass the pop up window.
trans-unit.target: Starting from 0.8.6, if you sign in using a work or school account, you can type the following command to bypass the pop up window.

trans-unit.source: This will pop up the standard Windows PowerShell credential window for you to enter your work or school account user name and password.
trans-unit.target: This will pop up the standard Windows PowerShell credential window for you to enter your work or school account user name and password.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information on security and using credentials, see [Best practices for deploying passwords and other sensitive data to ASP.NET and Azure Websites](http://www.asp.net/identity/overview/features-api/best-practices-for-deploying-passwords-and-other-sensitive-data-to-aspnet-and-azure).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information on security and using credentials, see [Best practices for deploying passwords and other sensitive data to ASP.NET and Azure Websites](http://www.asp.net/identity/overview/features-api/best-practices-for-deploying-passwords-and-other-sensitive-data-to-aspnet-and-azure).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This non-interactive login method only works with a work or school account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This non-interactive login method only works with a work or school account.

trans-unit.source: A work or school account is a user that is managed by your work or school, and defined in the Azure Active Directory instance for your work or school.
trans-unit.target: A work or school account is a user that is managed by your work or school, and defined in the Azure Active Directory instance for your work or school.

trans-unit.source: If you do not currently have a work or school account, and are using a Microsoft account to log in to your Azure subscription, you can easily create one using the following steps.
trans-unit.target: If you do not currently have a work or school account, and are using a Microsoft account to log in to your Azure subscription, you can easily create one using the following steps.

trans-unit.source: Login to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), and click on **Active Directory**.
trans-unit.target: Login to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), and click on **Active Directory**.

trans-unit.source: If no directory exists, select **Create your directory** and provide the requested information.
trans-unit.target: If no directory exists, select **Create your directory** and provide the requested information.

trans-unit.source: Select your directory and add a new user.
trans-unit.target: Select your directory and add a new user.

trans-unit.source: This new user can sign in using a work or school account.
trans-unit.target: This new user can sign in using a work or school account.

trans-unit.source: During the creation of the user, you will be supplied with both an e-mail address for the user and a temporary password.
trans-unit.target: During the creation of the user, you will be supplied with both an e-mail address for the user and a temporary password.

trans-unit.source: Save this information as it is used in another step.
trans-unit.target: Save this information as it is used in another step.

trans-unit.source: From the management portal, select **Settings** and then select **Administrators**.
trans-unit.target: From the management portal, select **Settings** and then select **Administrators**.

trans-unit.source: Select **Add**, and add the new user as a co-administrator.
trans-unit.target: Select **Add**, and add the new user as a co-administrator.

trans-unit.source: This allows the work or school account to manage your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: This allows the work or school account to manage your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Finally, log out of the Azure portal and then log back in using the work or school account.
trans-unit.target: Finally, log out of the Azure portal and then log back in using the work or school account.

trans-unit.source: If this is the first time logging in with this account, you will be prompted to change the password.
trans-unit.target: If this is the first time logging in with this account, you will be prompted to change the password.

trans-unit.source: For more information on signing up for Microsoft Azure with a work or school account, see [Sign up for Microsoft Azure as an Organization](sign-up-organization.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on signing up for Microsoft Azure with a work or school account, see [Sign up for Microsoft Azure as an Organization](sign-up-organization.md).

trans-unit.source: Use the certificate method
trans-unit.target: Use the certificate method

trans-unit.source: The Azure module includes cmdlets that help you download and import the certificate.
trans-unit.target: The Azure module includes cmdlets that help you download and import the certificate.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module require the Azure AD method (Add-AzureAccount).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module require the Azure AD method (Add-AzureAccount).

trans-unit.source: These cmdlets do not support publish settings files.
trans-unit.target: These cmdlets do not support publish settings files.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module, see [Azure Resource Manager Cmdlets](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394765).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module, see [Azure Resource Manager Cmdlets](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=394765).

trans-unit.source: The **Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile** cmdlet opens a web page on the
trans-unit.target: The **Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile** cmdlet opens a web page on the

trans-unit.source: Azure Management Portal, from which you can
trans-unit.target: Azure Management Portal, from which you can

trans-unit.source: download the subscription information.
trans-unit.target: download the subscription information.

trans-unit.source: The information is contained in a .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: The information is contained in a .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: The **Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile** imports the .publishsettings file for use by the module.
trans-unit.target: The **Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile** imports the .publishsettings file for use by the module.

trans-unit.source: This file includes a management certificate that has security credentials.
trans-unit.target: This file includes a management certificate that has security credentials.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] We recommend that you delete the publishing profile that you
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] We recommend that you delete the publishing profile that you

trans-unit.source: downloaded using Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile after you import those
trans-unit.target: downloaded using Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile after you import those

trans-unit.source: settings.
trans-unit.target: settings.

trans-unit.source: Because the management certificate includes security credentials, it
trans-unit.target: Because the management certificate includes security credentials, it

trans-unit.source: should not be accessed by unauthorized users.
trans-unit.target: should not be accessed by unauthorized users.

trans-unit.source: If you need information
trans-unit.target: If you need information

trans-unit.source: about your subscriptions, you can get it from the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com/) or the [Microsoft Online Services Customer Portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=324875).
trans-unit.target: about your subscriptions, you can get it from the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com/) or the [Microsoft Online Services Customer Portal](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=324875).

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com) using the credentials for your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure Management Portal](http://manage.windowsazure.com) using the credentials for your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: Open the Azure PowerShell console, as instructed in [How to: Install Azure PowerShell](#Install).
trans-unit.target: Open the Azure PowerShell console, as instructed in [How to: Install Azure PowerShell](#Install).

trans-unit.source: Type the following command:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command:

trans-unit.target: When prompted, download and save the publishing profile and note the path and name of

trans-unit.target: the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.target: This information is required when you run the

trans-unit.target: **Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile** cmdlet to import the settings.

trans-unit.target: The default

trans-unit.target: Type a command similar to the following, substituting your Windows account name and the path and file name for the placeholders:

trans-unit.target: process to download a new .publishsettings file, and then import those

trans-unit.source: View account and subscription details
trans-unit.target: View account and subscription details

trans-unit.source: You can have multiple accounts and subscriptions available for use by Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can have multiple accounts and subscriptions available for use by Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can add multiple accounts by running Add-AzureAccount more than once.
trans-unit.target: You can add multiple accounts by running Add-AzureAccount more than once.

trans-unit.target: To get the available Azure accounts, type:

trans-unit.source: How to use the cmdlets: An example
trans-unit.target: How to use the cmdlets: An example

trans-unit.source: After you've installed the module and configured your computer to connect to your subscription, you can create an Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: After you've installed the module and configured your computer to connect to your subscription, you can create an Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: This example will get you started using the Azure cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: This example will get you started using the Azure cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Start the Azure PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: Start the Azure PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: Choose a name for your web app.
trans-unit.target: Choose a name for your web app.

trans-unit.source: Pick a name that conforms to DNS naming conventions.
trans-unit.target: Pick a name that conforms to DNS naming conventions.

trans-unit.source: Valid names can contain only letters 'a' through 'z', numbers '0' through '9', and a hyphen ('-').
trans-unit.target: Valid names can contain only letters 'a' through 'z', numbers '0' through '9', and a hyphen ('-').

trans-unit.source: The web app name must be unique in Azure.
trans-unit.target: The web app name must be unique in Azure.

trans-unit.source: We'll use "mySite" in this example, but be sure to choose a different name, such as your account name followed by a number.
trans-unit.target: We'll use "mySite" in this example, but be sure to choose a different name, such as your account name followed by a number.

trans-unit.source: After you pick a name, type a command similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: After you pick a name, type a command similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: Substitute your web app name for "mySite".
trans-unit.target: Substitute your web app name for "mySite".

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet creates the web app and returns an object that represents the new web app.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet creates the web app and returns an object that represents the new web app.

trans-unit.source: The object properties include useful information about the web app.
trans-unit.target: The object properties include useful information about the web app.

trans-unit.source: To get information about the web app, type this command.
trans-unit.target: To get information about the web app, type this command.

trans-unit.source: It returns a bit of information about all web apps in the subscription, including the one that you just created.
trans-unit.target: It returns a bit of information about all web apps in the subscription, including the one that you just created.

trans-unit.source: To get more information about your web app, include the web app name in the command.
trans-unit.target: To get more information about your web app, include the web app name in the command.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to substitute the name of your web app for "mySite".
trans-unit.target: Be sure to substitute the name of your web app for "mySite".

trans-unit.source: Web apps are started after they are created.
trans-unit.target: Web apps are started after they are created.

trans-unit.source: To stop the web app, type this command, including the name of your web app.
trans-unit.target: To stop the web app, type this command, including the name of your web app.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the site's state is 'stopped', run the Get-AzureWebsite command again.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the site's state is 'stopped', run the Get-AzureWebsite command again.

trans-unit.source: To complete this test, delete the web app.
trans-unit.target: To complete this test, delete the web app.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: To complete the task, confirm that the web app is deleted.
trans-unit.target: To complete the task, confirm that the web app is deleted.

trans-unit.source: Getting Help
trans-unit.target: Getting Help

trans-unit.source: These resources provide help for specific cmdlets:
trans-unit.target: These resources provide help for specific cmdlets:

trans-unit.source: From within the console, you can use the built-in Help system.
trans-unit.target: From within the console, you can use the built-in Help system.

trans-unit.source: The **Get-Help** cmdlet provides access to this system.
trans-unit.target: The **Get-Help** cmdlet provides access to this system.

trans-unit.source: The following table provides some examples of commands you can use to get Help.
trans-unit.target: The following table provides some examples of commands you can use to get Help.

trans-unit.source: You can get more information from within the console by typing **help**.
trans-unit.target: You can get more information from within the console by typing **help**.

trans-unit.source: Command
trans-unit.target: Command

trans-unit.source: Result
trans-unit.target: Result

trans-unit.source: Get-Help
trans-unit.target: Get-Help

trans-unit.source: Describes how to use the Help system.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to use the Help system.

trans-unit.source: Note: The description includes some information about Help files that does not apply to the Azure module.
trans-unit.target: Note: The description includes some information about Help files that does not apply to the Azure module.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, Help files are installed when the module is installed.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, Help files are installed when the module is installed.

trans-unit.source: They are not available for download separately.
trans-unit.target: They are not available for download separately.

trans-unit.source: Get-Help Azure
trans-unit.target: Get-Help Azure

trans-unit.source: Gets all cmdlets in the Azure module.
trans-unit.target: Gets all cmdlets in the Azure module.

trans-unit.source: Get-Help <language>-dev
trans-unit.target: Get-Help <language>-dev

trans-unit.source: Gets cmdlets for developing and managing applications in a specific language.
trans-unit.target: Gets cmdlets for developing and managing applications in a specific language.

trans-unit.source: For example, help node-dev, help php-dev, or help python-dev.
trans-unit.target: For example, help node-dev, help php-dev, or help python-dev.

trans-unit.source: Get-Help <cmdlet>
trans-unit.target: Get-Help <cmdlet>

trans-unit.source: Gets help about a Windows PowerShell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Gets help about a Windows PowerShell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Replace
trans-unit.target: Replace

trans-unit.source: with the cmdlet name.
trans-unit.target: with the cmdlet name.

trans-unit.source: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Parameter *
trans-unit.target: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Parameter *

trans-unit.source: Gets descriptions of the cmdlet parameters.
trans-unit.target: Gets descriptions of the cmdlet parameters.

trans-unit.source: The asterisk (*) means "all".
trans-unit.target: The asterisk (*) means "all".

trans-unit.source: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Examples
trans-unit.target: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Examples

trans-unit.source: Gets the syntax and examples of using the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Gets the syntax and examples of using the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Full
trans-unit.target: Get-Help <cmdlet> -Full

trans-unit.source: Gets all help for a cmdlet, including technical details.
trans-unit.target: Gets all help for a cmdlet, including technical details.

trans-unit.source: Reference information about the cmdlets in the Azure PowerShell modules is also available in the Azure library.
trans-unit.target: Reference information about the cmdlets in the Azure PowerShell modules is also available in the Azure library.

trans-unit.source: For information, see [Azure Cmdlet Reference](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj554330.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For information, see [Azure Cmdlet Reference](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/jj554330.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For help from the community, try these popular forums:
trans-unit.target: For help from the community, try these popular forums:

trans-unit.source: Azure forum on MSDN
trans-unit.target: Azure forum on MSDN

trans-unit.source: Stackoverflow
trans-unit.target: Stackoverflow

trans-unit.source: Additional Resources
trans-unit.target: Additional Resources

trans-unit.source: These are some of the resources available that you can use to learn to use Azure and Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: These are some of the resources available that you can use to learn to use Azure and Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: To learn about how to access Azure Storage components, see [Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage](storage-powershell-guide-full.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn about how to access Azure Storage components, see [Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Storage](storage-powershell-guide-full.md).

trans-unit.source: To provide feedback about the cmdlets, report issues, or access the source code, see [Azure PowerShell code repository](https://github.com/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-tools).
trans-unit.target: To provide feedback about the cmdlets, report issues, or access the source code, see [Azure PowerShell code repository](https://github.com/WindowsAzure/azure-sdk-tools).

trans-unit.source: To learn about the Windows PowerShell command line and scripting environment, see the [TechNet Script Center](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320211).
trans-unit.target: To learn about the Windows PowerShell command line and scripting environment, see the [TechNet Script Center](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320211).

trans-unit.source: For information about installing, learning, using, and customizing Windows PowerShell, see [Scripting with Windows PowerShell](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320210).
trans-unit.target: For information about installing, learning, using, and customizing Windows PowerShell, see [Scripting with Windows PowerShell](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320210).

trans-unit.source: For information about what scripts are and how to run them in Windows PowerShell, see [Running Scripts](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320627).
trans-unit.target: For information about what scripts are and how to run them in Windows PowerShell, see [Running Scripts](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320627).

trans-unit.source: This article includes basic information about creating scripts and configuring your computer to run scripts.
trans-unit.target: This article includes basic information about creating scripts and configuring your computer to run scripts.

trans-unit.source: For information about cmdlets for Azure AD, see [Manage Azure AD using Windows PowerShell](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320628).
trans-unit.target: For information about cmdlets for Azure AD, see [Manage Azure AD using Windows PowerShell](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=320628).
